captions.text:
Good morning, John. You and I were lucky enough
be raised in a country where we got free education

for twelve years. We just didn't have to pay
for it. You of course did pay for some of

it, because you had to go to a fancy boarding
school, though I guess that turned out okay

with the book you wrote, because of that and
all.

That level of free education is pretty remarkable,
it's a pretty cool thing. We don't think about

it but, you know, I learned a lot of good
stuff. I learned how to read, how to do algebra,

plate tectonics, what a mole is, how to play
marimba, er... speak some Spanish.

It was a nice gift that society gave to me,
and I didn't hate every minute of it, but

that did not stop me from complaining about
it constantly. Of course since I was not the

brightest glow stick in the pack, the things
that I was complaining about, were kind of

terrible. But the American education system
does have some problems, and I want to talk

about two of the kind of interrelated ones
right now.

First, for me, here's what education is: it's
building a toolkit with which to solve problems,

and applying that toolkit in the solving of
problems. You've got to have the necessary

tools and the skills to use them. Now that
involves knowing lots of discrete pieces of
information. But it is much more than that.

Like, we don't learn the alphabet because
it's good to know some completely arbitrary

letters in an order. We learn it because it
helps us learn how to read and write, and

reading and writing solves the problem of
the impermanence of spoken words. We can write

things down and then they'll last much longer
than if we just say them which is... they
last this long and then it's gone.

Everything taught in schools should be designed
to increase our collective problem solving

toolkit, and all the things that are taught
do that. US History does that and long division

does that. And some of the problems are solved
just by having a more informed populace, like

having people who all know the same things
and can agree on some basic stuff. Like it

would be really great, I think, it would solve
a lot of problems if we had a gender studies
course that was required in high school.

But what I remember is a lot of shoving facts
in to my short term memory so that I could

do well on a test and then forgetting them
immediately, and that did not make my toolkit

more robust. The only thing it really taught
me was how to do well on tests which I eventually
got pretty good at. That's my first problem.

Second, the toolkit that we develop in school,
and out of school, is the thing that we will

use for the rest of our lives to solve problems
personally and professionally, and professionally

solving problems is what you call a job. But
if everyone gets the same toolkit in school

then we have a glut, we have an oversupply
of people with that toolkit, and when supply

outstrips demand, well, I learned all about
that in my economics class that I had to wait
until college to take.

I worry about there not being a broad enough
diversity of toolkits. This is why at Crash

Course, which is our educational YouTube channel,
youtube.com/crashcourse, we're starting to

look into topics that are a little bit more
off the beaten path. We've just started anatomy

and physiology two weeks ago; there's two
episodes of that up now. That's basically

the study of your body, how it works, why
it works and when it breaks what happens.

And we also just yesterday launched Crash
Course: Astronomy hosted by Phil Plait who

is an astronomer and science communicator
that I kind of can't believe I get to work

with. So youtube.com/crashcourse, you can
learn about your body and your solar system.

And speaking of things that I cannot believe,
and you may have been waiting for this, President

Obama who just announced that he's going to
try and make two years of community college

free for all students, thus broadening the
toolkit of Americans, thumbs up on that one,

is going to have a little conversation with
me in which we are going to hopefully talk

about some issues that matter to people of
America.

You may not be people of America, but if you
are, then please leave things that you would

like me to talk about or thoughts that you
have in the comments or on various social

media you can use the hashtag #YOUTUBEASKSOBAMA,
this one right there, there it is. It will

be live streamed; you can watch it on the
White House's YouTube channel on January 22nd.

That's Thursday. I promise I won't puke. Fwaa,
just talking about freaks me out. Leave your

questions, that will help me; I'll appreciate
that. I put an American flag back behind me

for the occasion, and I'm wearing red, red
and blue. So look at me, I'm totally pro-ing
it up.
Alright John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.text:
You didn't get ecenomics in highschool? In holland it is accually based on 
a system where student get to choose a vague direction of study's in 
hieghscool already. There are 4 (basic) choices witch are: " Linguistic and 
artistic studies" , " Ecenomics" , "Physycs and biology" and lastly 
"Physics and technological studies". All these choices have a diffrent 
curriculum although all of them still have a base of classes thet must 
take. Like Dutch, Englisch, one more language(frensh, erman or in some 
schools spanisch), and some form of social studies. Also a student can 
expand these curiculums by doin any class off there choice that is not 
whitin the set curiculum. This way the toolset is already diffirentiated at 
a younger age and while it is intended to still go to collage after that at 
least students can focus on the direction they want to go in a little 
sooner and don't have to cram stuff in to their heads thay have no interest 
in. This partly solves the only doing well on a test problem because 
students learn stuff that they want to know and are interested in. (sorry 
for the bad spelling) ;)﻿

comments.author: Jallorn

comments.text:
I will say that standardized education has a few important advantages:
1. Equality. Schools are mostly funded by property taxes, which is a rather 
big problem for kids in low-income communities. More running, evaluating, 
and most especially funding of schools at higher levels of government tends 
to mean a more equal chance to get educated for everyone.
2. College. When somebody goes into social movements 100 in order to get 
their gen-ed social science, it's helpful if they have a decent 
understanding of the Harlem Renaissance. Professors need to be able to 
count on students doing a gen-ed requirement having certain universal 
skills.
3. The toolkit. There are a few vital skills that every student should have 
(basic economics, sociology, political science, mathematics, 
civics/government, physical and environmental science, logic, etc.), and it 
is vital that somebody make sure that students do, indeed, have them, and 
don't get screwed over by where they live. 

That said, I agree that the US system of standardized testing is screwed up 
in a variety of ways.

comments.text:
i love how the comment section is flooded with people trying to discredit 
standardized testing and wanting every student to be treated with velvet 
gloves. guess what:
you need a standard school model to compare the performances of every 
student under the same circumstances. you can't give everyone straight A's, 
loosen up the curriculum so everybody can work at their own pace, what's 
the point even in grading people then. there is a bar set you have to 
achieve, the harder you work for it the better do your grades get and your 
academic and professional career is based on your grades because 
universities and employers want the best people there are available.
on standardized testing: how the fuck else would you try to determine the 
abilities of the students other than through exams that are standardized 
and on an equal level for everyone. this term is being used as though 
studying for it only consists of dull memorizing of facts that just need to 
be written down in the exam, which is bullshit. in advanced education most 
exams are set to test your transfer of learning and knowledge transfer, 
meaning you are taught facts but not in a manner of "learning by heart" but 
in order to learn how to deduce information from given facts and think in 
order to solve problems.
the fact that there are people who get better grades than others doesn't 
automatically mean that the education system is flawed, on the contrary. it 
just means that there are people with different strengths and weaknesses, 
people who are talented in different fields, which is just natural.﻿

comments.author: Eagle III Films

comments.text:
Our school system is designed so that you're put in a room with a teacher, 
and if you don't do well, they put you in a computer lab. It should be the 
other way around. People should be able to take and pass courses in public 
school at their own pace. We should not base your public education level on 
your age. While this system would reduce the number of teacher required, it 
would also allow us to pay teachers like real professionals (the same 6 
figure professional salaries and benefits you see given to doctors, 
lawyers, and engineers) so that we could not only attract the best talent, 
but have a system that retains the best of the best by requiring the same 
professional development to become a teacher in the first place (i.e. 
advanced degrees from "educator school" similar to "law school" and 
"medical school") and rigorous evaluations afterward. I see a lot of 
promise in what they are doing with Khan Academy, but it needs a little 
development and public support (funding).﻿

comments.text:
guess what, that's like literally every european education system ever and 
it works fine. I'm attending university right now in germany and kept 
living at my parents' for the first few months because I couldn't afford my 
own place yet (even though the university is 70km from my home town) and 
guess what, it's not inherently bad to live with your parents while 
attending higher education. moved closer to the university at last now, I 
pay 300€ a semester for it, state pays a quarter million for my entire 
education there and guess what, our government still isn't broke because it 
doesn't pay as much for other things like the military, but that's an 
entirely different discussion.
my point being: don't criticize it just because you have been living in a 
different system that you've gotten used to. and spending money on 
educating the nation is definitely, definitely worth it.

comments.author: Lordofzeldafed

comments.text:
I am a sophomore community college student, and college has helped me with 
life problems more than anything else, not to mention simply learning about 
what actually goes on in the world.  If you take logic you can learn how to 
identify any flaw in an argument; an argument is a statement with reasons 
backing it up.  If you take philosophy101, you should leave questioning 
your faith, as well as all others.If you take archaeology, you will see the 
evidence for evolution. If you take biomedical ethics, a philosophy course, 
you will learn how public policy on controversial topics like abortion is 
determined.  When you take English 102, you learn how to write at a college 
level, where any mistake is accounted for. If you take social and political 
philosophy, you will learn about the purpose of government.  If you take 
archaeology, you will see the evidence for evolution. Let's not forget that 
the people teaching these wonderful classes are professors, who have a 
doctorate in their respective field, and who are all top-notch role models. 
These are the toolkits school ought to provide, and provided by the ones 
that ought to be doing so. The few grand per semester i've spent has been 
priceless for the knowledge i've gained.  Community college should be 
priceless.﻿

comments.author: Danny Cruz (OboeFiles)

comments.text:
My problem with education is that the things we are taught are things not 
everyone needs and for some are nothing but boring or stressful to learn. 
Not everyone needs algebra, science and history and if people don't want to 
pursue careers in those subjects, they shouldn't be forced to learn about 
them. Algebra especially. Algebra is something that you either understand 
or don't understand and the people that don't understand it get overwhelmed 
very easily by it. I am one of those people. It's stressed me out to the 
point of going into a panic attack on multiple occasions. It should not be 
mandatory for someone to continue to learn about something that isn't 
valuable to them and stresses them out to that point. Science and history 
were interesting as a child, but now they're just boring and annoying. I 
don't need them for the jobs I'd like to go into, so they're useless to me. 
I think the school system should work as this: science, math/algebra and 
history should be mandatory until high school. In high school they should 
become optional classes so the people who are interested in them can 
continue them and the people that aren't don't have to be forced to 
continue to learn things they have no interest in. By high school 
everything has been introduced to you, even basic algebra, so you'll know 
if you want to continue learning about them or not. The required classes 
should be things everyone needs like classes about how to preform basic 
first aid, sex ed classes that go into way more depth than they do, classes 
about how to properly take care of a child since they always talk about 
using a condom to prevent having kid but tell you nothing about how to go 
about actually having one and taking care of it if you want one, a class 
dedicated just to laws and our human rights because yes they are taught in 
history, but it was brief and I barely remember any of it because I was 
taught it at a very young age, classes about how money works, classes about 
if buying a house or apartment and if it's better to rent or buy and other 
things. Stuff like that is what we should be required to learn. Not stuff 
that isn't useful for everyone. And then they should still have other 
optional classes on the side for things that people actually want to do 
like art, music, computer and acting classes. If the education system 
worked like that, people wouldn't be as stressed, overwhelmed and miserable 
because of school. Also I am sorry this is so long, wow, I am just really 
passionate about my views on how school should work, eheh... I am done 
now. ﻿

system: I agree, as a recent graduate of it and as a current worker within 
it, that there are major issues & problems with public education; however, 
there were no solutions offered here to counteract the problems mentioned. 
Yes recognizing the issue is the first step, but we have already done that. 
Now, we need to have meaningful solutions offered, implemented, and tested 
to actually fix the broken system.﻿

comments.author: Tejveer Oberoi

comments.text:
I was looking through the comments, and I see a lot of people bashing on 
common core so let set a few things straight.  One thing that people must 
realize, is that the main purpose of the common core is to make schools 
teach. Before common core a school could say, hey I don't want to go 
through the work to hire a new science teacher, so were just not going to 
teach them science. While many see the common core as a bad thing in many 
ways it holds schools accountable. My mother is a high school astronomy and 
geology teacher so I've been able to see the difference common core has 
made. Before it was put into action my mom had students coming into her 
class thinking that the earth was the center of our solar system and that 
our core contained another world with dinosaurs. It's not that they weren't 
intelligent or that they had never been to school they had been going to 
school since kindergarten like any other kid. Their elementary and jr. high 
simply didn't want to teach it to them. Now, not all schools are this bad I 
realize this, but there are places that are even worse. Common core isn't 
perfect but its certainly better than what we had. ﻿

comments.text:
The government shouldn't have any control over school and education 
systems! That power constitutionally resides with states or counties. 
Students living in NYC need different amenities, time standards, and such 
than students living in Kavik, Alaska. The government has already intruded 
in our taxes, our ownership rights, our marriages, and the last thing 
America needs is the gov't intruding in our schools. With a couple 
exceptions, the US system is flawed. Schools are run on political biases on 
both wings and it is extremely hard to fire teachers who are driven by 
political machines to teach their students politically biased information. 
It will hurt America's future, and change the meanings of both the 
Republican and Denocratic parties. ﻿

comments.text:
There is should be a set level of mathematics, and the exact naming of 
types of math needed to be studied. Also it would be efficient, for a 
reading comprehension test on the Constitution as well as test on the 
vocabulary worlds contained in the U.S. Constitution. Students should take 
a detailed test on deductive and inductive reasoning with Aristotelian 
syllogisms. This would help the nation clearly analyze laws and goals that 
are spoken of in political speeches; people would be able to more readily 
tell the difference between charisma and good logic being put forward by 
political leaders, and anyone else for that matter.﻿
comments.author: Bruce Wayne

comments.text:
You're right about education in America (and a lot of other western 
countries with a similar mindset -the UK for example) reducing education to 
shoe-horning "exam knowledge" into the minds of kids. As a Science teacher 
I've seen a lot of educators remove practical activities from lessons so 
they can focus on that shoe-horning.

I know it's important to pass exams, but students learn in a variety of 
different ways, so injecting... a variety of different learning styles, and 
fun, into lessons will take the pressure off students and encourage 
engagement in class.﻿
comments.author: Jim Bowen

comments.author: cmcaggia3

comments.text:
I really agree with your comment about the diversity of the "toolkit" 
people get in education being important. I do think there are some problems 
with uniformity in education in the U.S.

Another topic or topics that I think is also a weakness of the U.S. 
educational system is self-awareness and communication skills, things like 
assertiveness training, awareness of one's own thought process, and the 
relationship between thoughts and emotions.  I also think learning about 
how to express disagreement in respectful ways, could be helpful.  I think 
learning about this sort of stuff could improve mental health (i.e. 
learning skills like some of the things Cognitive Behavioral Therapy 
teaches) and also reduce group conflict.

Lastly, I think another big failure of the U.S. educational system is in 
giving students freedom.  Students in the U.S. spend more hours in school 
than students in Europe, and they often are programmed and scheduled 
outside of school.  As a result, I don't think they develop good time 
management skills until college, and I think they also miss out on a lot of 
opportunities to take initiative and learn how to start and organize things 
themselves.  These skills are critical for most jobs and careers, and 
especially so for entrepreneurs, who are the driving force of the economy 
and key players in job creation, as well as in solving problems in society.

So I would love to see the educational system scale back the number of 
hours students spend in school, and scale back the amount of assigned work, 
and give students more structured time, more opportunities to do 
self-directed reading and exploration, etc.  I find it ironic that in most 
of my schools, in spite of being forced to be in school 7 hours a day, we 
were not allowed into the school early, nor allowed to stay late.  So it's 
like, we're not able to operate the way true scholars do, where you can go 
into the library of your own initiative, or the science lab, or the 
computer lab, or a lounge, to discuss things with peers.  That's the sort 
of environment that I really want to see us start creating, and I think we 
could even start at a very young age.﻿
comments.author: Alex Zorach

comments.text: I agree

comments.author: Reina N

comments.text:
Here is the problem, its not that we all have the same tool kit, its that 
we have tools we don't need and are missing tools we do need. Facts are we 
will never need calculus, but we don't know the importance of voting, or we 
don't need advanced biology but we don't know how to budget our incomes, 
pay taxes, or fill out check books. 

We need mandatory classes that teach us to be adults, and mandatory classes 
for those who want to take these advanced courses for a career path we wish 
to take.﻿

comments.author: Kugel

comments.text:
So, I'm watching this video from the other side of the globe. I am from 
Germany, and here you have the duty to got to school for a minimum of ten 
years, and the other 2 (or three, it depends on which state you are in) 
years of school are somewhat free to choose. We talked about some states in 
America, where things like evolution are forbidden in school, and kids 
learn things from the bible in biology. That seemed rather strange to us, 
since we thought common sense is , well, common. But I really want to know: 
Are there really some states where teachers are not allowed to teach 
evolutionary theories in science classes , but instead have to teach 
religious thoughts on that topic? And if so, how does the rest of the 
american States think about this kind of ignorance? Since every person, no 
matter what age , gender or state he lives in should be allowed to form his 
own opinion on stuff like that, and the government is trying to keep those 
theories away from them.﻿
comments.author: Felix Maiwald

comments.text:
This guys view of what education is fits into complete Utopia disconnected 
from reality, but he's only a young guy, and probably went to a school wich 
was nice. I hope you find wisdom sooner than later. First, you education of 
course is NOT "free", it is payed for by the sweat of working people every 
day. We should demand the best education possible for our children, we have 
the right to because it comes from our hard work.

Elite schools and alternative private schools, even from first grade, are a 
completely different planet from normal shools. Corriculum, social order, 
student teacher relationships, everything.
And the results are obvious that upper class families stay upper class 
generation after generation.
Poor inner city families stay poor and inner city-educated generation after 
generation.

One group learns how to think and goes on to careers and creative ideas, 
the other learns nothing and has to compete for a job on the others factory.

Early part of normal schooling is about children learning to interact with, 
and fit in with society in their place. What is acceptable behaviour - what 
you should and should not say - wich social group you are comfortable with 
- basic rules that apply universally.

It is to instill all of our diverse, differently thinking individuals with 
at least ONE homogenous premise with wich to see the world as they become 
adults.

And its the same in every democratic-valued country in the west. Its the 
"land of the free, home of the brave, you can accomplish anything you put 
your mind too. you are a citizen in a free country where we people ARE all 
equal, all people get ONE Vote both rich and poor, the founding fathers 
were great men"

Its all the same but applicable to the country we are talking about. It is 
a divisive social factor early on that teaches things that are very hard to 
overcome. Infact school leads us to exactly where we are supposed to be 
according to the social order. A teacher can tell be second grade who will 
end up in prison, who will be an addict, who will be violent, everyone 
knows this. We dont change it because most dont see it after being 
instilled with the premise that we are all free and your life is in your 
hands, "if you work hard enough", and so forth﻿
comments.author: legennd3

comments.text: Crash course physics? :)﻿

comments.author: William Feagin

comments.text:
Community College needs to stop JUST being a place for the first 2 years of 
G.E. and start being more of a vocational training ground again. There a 
tons of for profit vocational colleges now because community college 
doesn't offer vocational training anymore. That is just sooo ridiculous. 
There already tons of people who are getting degrees who don't have jobs 
and perhaps we in this country OVER value education.

Higher education is there so people can get jobs for there niche industry 
or subject. Not everyone is going to be a doctor, scientist, physiologist 
or social worker. :/ Jobs of the "future" might not all be high level jobs. 
What about the speciality mid-level jobs? I would argue that the job 
training for that is more essential.

For instance, the dialysis industry is going to grow because the prevalence 
of people with diabetes and high blood pressure in the country. So with 
that in mind in my city the 4 years growth would be, 2-3 more nephrologists 
in the city but that equals to like 30 dialysis techs, 9 nurses and a 
secretary. So basically it is 3 high level job for every 40 mid/"low" level 
job.  :/ The dialysis center I worked at HAD a classes for nurses and 
certified dialysis techs in the Community College but was CUT because "the 
community college wasn't making money." Those people get hired after for a 
jobs that pays $13-$15 (after +3 years experience... I think like $10 
starting) an hr + 1 1/2 after 8 hours and they work 12 hour shifts. They 
still have classes but it is private now and the class is $6,000+ dollars. _; 
It should have STAYED at the community college. <.<;﻿
comments.author: Bitter Tea

comments.text:
My Concerns: 1. Class Room Space || 2. How people will use the 2 years like 
zombies and not think about a general plan for themselves || 3. People will 
not value the 2 years of college the same way they do not value the 12 
years of school people get because it is free.

Community College is over crowded in my State. There is already a 
Governor's waiver so people of a certain income get to go there free for 4 
years. The issue is that it is over crowded as heck. I hope somewhere in 
that plan there is a plan to build more schools for all the people going to 
take the 2 year courses because there is already going to be an influx. If 
the budget is just to pay for the new people and does not go into 
infrastructure, then there is an big problem!

For the hardworking people who plan to transfer to a 4 year college, I feel 
it is a good idea. 2 years of free school full of just G.E. is a total 
waste for people with no intention to transfer. Associates degrees aren't 
valued in terms of hiring, from what I hear. Maybe some G.E. and a year of 
a specific vocation might be best for some people, whether they recognize 
it or not and that is the problem. Medical assistant, dental assistant and 
automobiles is a respectable profession. Everyone doesn't have to be a 
social work or psychologist. <.<;

A teacher I knew taught high school and while there are a few hard working 
students, some people are there because "they have to be there" and so they 
just use that time to hangout with friends. That holds the other students 
back. He felt like a baby sitter and had to divide the problem students 
from everyone else. One student just would spend the day pealing the top of 
the table off the desk. I just hope the first two years of CC don't become 
13 and 14 grade. <.<;

But I generally like the idea and support education. ;D﻿
